nodes.text: Economic decision-making and market dynamics can be modeled using a quantum probabilistic propensity framework that replaces classical utility with a propensity function and incorporates quantum effects such as superposition, interference, and entanglement
A propensity function specifies the probability that an agent will take a particular decision and can be interpreted as the squared amplitude of an underlying quantum wave function

Quantum probability with a 2-norm naturally models phenomena in human decision-making such as superposition, interference, entanglement, order effects, disjunction effect, and preference reversal which classical utility-based approaches struggle to capture

A simple two-qubit quantum circuit using unitary rotations A and B and a C-NOT gate can simulate sequences of context-influenced decisions and reproduce the order effect and related probabilistic patterns

Quantizing a general propensity function yields quantum dynamics for financial transactions, enabling definitions of entropic force, economic mass, frequency (resistance to change), and energy associated with changing propensity

A continuous propensity distribution (e.g., normal) can be represented as the ground state probability distribution of a quantum harmonic oscillator, connecting propensity variance to an effective economic mass m = hbar / (2 omega sigma squared)
Mapping propensity to a quantum wave function permits negative and complex amplitudes, which enable interference effects when unitary transformations (e.g., Hadamard, rotations) are applied

Empirical cognitive phenomena like preference reversal and the disjunction effect can be modeled by interpreting context as a quantum gate A and decision as gate B in the circuit, with entanglement capturing social or contextual correlations

Mathematically the two-qubit circuit psi_f = Xc (A otimes B) psi_0 yields joint outcome probabilities equivalent to sequential projection measurements for appropriate choices of unitary A and B, demonstrating circuit flexibility
An entropic force can be defined from a propensity distribution P(x) as F(x) = gamma P'(x)/P(x), giving a dynamics interpretation where gamma has units of energy related to information

For a normal propensity P(x) with mean mu and sd sigma, the entropic force is linear F(x) = -k(x-mu) with k = gamma / sigma squared, and economic mass varies inversely with variance making narrow propensities higher mass

A quantitative threshold criterion for preference reversal is that a switch occurs only if the cost ratio x2/x1 > 3, and the information energy required to change propensity is of order (hbar omega)/2 log 3 approx (hbar omega)/2
